div1.head: Congressional Bill #S. 2817, 71st Congress, 2d Session, December 13, 1929
div1.p:
IN THE SENATE OF THE UNITED STATES
DECEMBER 13 (calendar day, DECEMBER 21), 1929

Mr. SHEPPARD introduced the following bill; which was read twice and referred
to the Committee on Military Affairs
-------------------------------
✓

To amend an Act entitled “An Act to recognize the high public
service rendered by Major Walter Reed and those associated
with him in the discovery of the cause and means of trans-
mission of yellow fever,” approved February 28, 1929, by
including Roger P. Ames among those honored by said Act.

1 Be it enacted by the Senate and House of Representa-
2 tives of the United States of America in Congress assembled,
3 That the Act entitled “An Act to recognize the high public
4 service rendered by Major Walter Reed and those associated
5 with him in the discovery of the cause and means of trans-
6 mission of yellow fever,” approved February 28, 1929, be,
7 and the same is hereby, amended by inserting between the
8 names “Aristides Agramonte” and “James A. Andrus”
2
1 the name “Roger P. Ames,” so that the Act as amended
2 will read as follows:

3 “That in special recognition of the high public service
4 rendered and disabilities contracted in the interest of human-
5 ity and science as voluntary subjects for the experimenta-
6 tions during the yellow-fever investigations in Cuba, the
7 Secretary of War be, and he is hereby, authorized and di-
8 rected to publish annually in the Army Register a roll of
9 honor on which shall be carried the following names: Walter
10 Reed, James Carroll, Jesse W. Lazear, Aristides Agramonte,
11 Roger P. Ames, James A. Andrus, John R. Bullard, A. W.
12 Covington, William H. Dean, Wallace W. Forbes, Levi E.
13 Folk, Paul Hamann, James F. Hanberry, Warren G. Jerne-
14 gan, John R. Kissinger, John J. Moran, William Olsen,
15 Charles G. Sonntag, Clyde L. West, Doctor R. P. Cooke,
16 Thomas M. England, James Hildebrand, and Edward
17 Weatherwalks, and to define in appropriate language the
18 part which each of these persons played in the experimenta-
19 tions during the yellow-fever investigations in Cuba; and in
20 further recognition of the high public service so rendered
21 by the persons hereinbefore named, the Secretary of the
22 Treasury is authoirzed and directed to cause to be struck for
23 each of said persons a gold medal with suitable emblems,
24 devices, and inscriptions, to be determined by the Secretary
25 of the Treasury, and to present the same to each of said
3
1 persons as shall be living and posthumously to such repre-
2 sentatives of each of such persons as shall have died, as shall
3 be designated by the Secretary of the Treasury. For this
4 purpose there is hereby authorized to be appropriated the
5 sum of $5,000; and there is hereby authorized to be appro-
6 priated, out of any money in the Treasury not otherwise
7 appropriated, such amounts annually as may be necessary
8 in order to pay to the following-named persons during the
9 remainder of their natural lives the sum of $125 per month,
10 and such amount shall be in lieu of any and all pensions
11 authorized by law for the following-named persons: Private
12 Paul Hamann; Private John R. Kissinger; Private William
13 Olsen, Hospital Corps; Private Charles G. Sonntag, Hos-
14 pital Corps; Private Clyde L. West, Hospital Corps; Private
15 James Hildebrand, Hospital Corps, Private James A. Andrus,
16 Hospital Corps; Mr. John R. Bullard; Doctor Aristides
17 Agramonte; Private A. W. Covington, Twenty-third Bat-
18 tery, Coast Artillery Corps; Private Wallace W. Forbes,
19 Hospital Corps; Private Levi E. Folk, Hospital Corps;
20 Private James F. Hanberry, Hospital Corps; Doctor R. P.
21 Cooke; Private Thomas M. England; Mr. John J. Moran,
22 and the widow of Private Edward Weatherwalks.”
